image_1.description: Fernando Ortíz was a 50-year-old professor who was kidnapped in 1976 during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Chile. He is also depicted in a photograph held by a man with curly hair, wearing a checkered shirt and earrings, holding a red flower and a black-and-white photograph.

Simón Bolívar is the name of the secret torture center where many, including Fernando Ortíz, were taken and never returned, as run by the regime’s intelligence agency, DINA, during Pinochet's dictatorship.
Gen. Augusto Pinochet was the dictator of Chile from 1973 to 1990, during which time numerous people, including Fernando Ortíz, were abducted and disappeared.

Chile is the country where the military rule led to the disappearance of 1,469 people from 1973 to 1990, and where a national search plan has been enacted to find the remaining disappeared. It is also the location of the secret torture center named Simón Bolívar.
Gabriel Boric is the President of Chile who signed a presidential decree to codify the national search plan for the disappeared.
Luis Cordero is Chile’s minister of justice and human rights, who has emphasized the state's responsibility in the search for the disappeared.
National Search Plan is the initiative enacted by Chile to track down the remaining disappeared people before the 50th anniversary of the coup.

image_2.description: Hurricane Idalia, a Category 3 hurricane when it made landfall, caused significant damage along Florida's western coast, including flooded neighborhoods, wind damage, and two deaths due to traffic accidents. It also affected Cedar Key and Crystal River, with residents experiencing howling winds, flying debris, and rising floodwaters. The hurricane was later downgraded to a tropical storm, impacting Georgia and South Carolina.

Cedar Key is a group of tiny islands in Florida where Hurricane Idalia caused significant effects, with residents like Donna Knight describing a night of howling winds, frightening bangs, and flying debris.
Crystal River is a coastal city in Florida where residents, including Doug Nicholson, experienced rising floodwaters due to Hurricane Idalia.
An area with standing water, debris, and damaged structures, indicating recent flooding as a result of Hurricane Idalia.

image_3.description: A building with yellow and red doors, partially submerged in floodwaters in Cedar Key, Florida. The building has two windows with fish paintings and numbers 14 and 15 on the doors.
A road surrounded by trees and covered in floodwaters in Florida, showing tire tracks indicating recent vehicle movement.

Hurricane Idalia, a Category 3 hurricane when it made landfall, caused flooding and wind damage in Florida's coastal regions, including Horseshoe Beach, Cedar Key, and Crystal River, resulting in two deaths due to traffic accidents.

image_4.description: The Cowichan River in Canada is a geographical location that experienced the biggest die-off in living memory, potentially due to climate change, as described in the text.
A dense forest with tall evergreen trees, creating a lush green canopy, as depicted in the image and not directly mentioned in the text.

image_5.description: A woman with a visible neck and chin, wearing a yellow garment and a detailed necklace, which features intricate patterns and possibly made of beads or similar materials.

image_6.description: A sign with the US Open logo on a hedge, related to the event of the same name which is demanding for tennis players.
